metadata.title: The treatment strategy for tracheoesophageal fistula

sections.abstract: With the development of endoscopic techniques, the treatment of tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) has made marked progress. As surgical intervention is often not an advisable option due to advanced malignancy and poor performance status of the patients, bronchoscopic intervention provides a good choice to palliate symptoms and reconstruct the airway and esophagus. In this review, we focus on the application of interventional therapy of TEF, especially the application of airway stenting, and highlight some representative cases referred to our department for treatment.
sections.methods: Narrative review of interventional management strategies for tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF), emphasizing airway and esophageal stenting approaches. Includes a single-center case series from the authors' department (July 2013 to June 2015) of 61 consecutive TEF patients treated with airway stenting (43 metallic covered stents; 18 silicone Dumon stents), with definitions for clinical response (complete, partial, failure) assessed using contrast radiography and symptom resolution at >2 weeks.
sections.results: In the single-center series (n=61), overall clinical response (complete or partial) was achieved in all patients. Metallic stent group (n=43): complete response 28 (65.1%), partial response 15 (34.9%). Of 25 patients who underwent double stenting (airway + esophageal), 24 (96%) achieved complete response. Silicone (Dumon) stent group (n=18): complete response 13 (72.2%), partial response 5 (27.8%). All 10 patients who underwent double stenting achieved complete response. Authors conclude metallic and silicone stents show equivalent effects, with slightly higher complete response in silicone group (P>0.05).

population.text: Adults with tracheoesophageal fistula (mostly malignant) managed at a single respiratory center.
inclusion_criteria: Endoscopically and/or radiographically confirmed tracheoesophageal fistula

intervention.text: Airway stenting (metallic covered or silicone Dumon), with or without concurrent esophageal stenting (double stenting).
intervention.details: Stent type selected based on fistula size/location, airway anatomy, and feasibility. Stents sized to cover ≥20 mm beyond fistula margins; diameter 10-20% larger than adjacent airway. Double stenting used when airway compromise risk from esophageal stent, stent-induced TEF, large fistula (>20 mm), or to prevent migration.

comparison.text: Non-randomized comparison of stent material (metallic vs silicone) within a single-arm case series.
comparison.details: Crude, unadjusted comparison of complete response rates by stent type; subset analysis for double stenting.

outcomes.name: Complete clinical response at ≥2 weeks (no contrast leak and symptom resolution)

analysis_populations.name: All treated
analysis_populations.description: All patients receiving airway stenting during the study period

provenance.quote: In metallic stent group, there were 28 cases (65.1%) which achieved complete response and 15 cases (34.9%) with a partial response... In the silicone stent group, 13 cases (72.2%) obtained a complete response while 5 cases (27.8%) were a partial response... Metallic stents and silicone stents show equivalent clinical effects. However, the rate of complete response is slightly higher in silicone stent group (P>0.05).

retrieval.summary_tldr: Single-center case series (n=61) of TEF managed with airway stenting showed universal clinical response (complete or partial); complete response was 65.1% with metallic vs 72.2% with silicone stents (P>0.05), and double stenting achieved near-100% complete response.
retrieval.clinical_relevance: Supports endoscopic airway and combined airway-esophageal stenting as effective palliation for TEF, with high rates of fistula sealing and symptom relief.
